io.atomix

Class Atomix

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.atomix.Atomix
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Managed<Atomix>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AtomixClient, AtomixReplica

    public abstract class Atomix
extends Object
implements Managed<Atomix>
    Base type for creating and managing distributed resources in a Atomix cluster.

    Resources are user provided stateful objects backed by a distributed state machine. This class facilitates the creation and management of Resource objects via a filesystem like interface. There is a one-to-one relationship between keys and resources, so each key can be associated with one and only one resource.

    To create a resource, pass the resource Class to the create(String, ResourceType) method. When a resource is created, the StateMachine associated with the resource will be created on each Raft server and future operations submitted for that resource will be applied to the state machine. Internally, resource state machines are multiplexed across a shared Raft log.

    Resource implementations serve as a user-friendly interface through which to submit commands and queries to the underlying CopycatClient client.

    Author:
    Jordan Halterman

    • Method Detail

      • context

        public ThreadContext context()
        Returns the Atomix thread context.

        This context is representative of the thread on which asynchronous callbacks will be executed for this Atomix instance. Atomix guarantees that all CompletableFutures supplied by this instance will be executed via the returned context. Users can use the context to access the thread-local Serializer.

        Returns:
        The Atomix thread context.

      • exists

        public CompletableFuture<Boolean> exists(String key)
        Checks whether a resource exists with the given key.

        If no resource with the given key exists in the cluster, the returned CompletableFuture will be completed false. Note, however, that users should not significantly rely upon the existence or non-existence of a resource due to race conditions. While a resource may not exist when the returned future is completed, it may be created by another node shortly thereafter.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   if (!atomix.exists("lock").get()) {
     DistributedLock lock = atomix.create("lock", DistributedLock::new).get();
   }
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.exists("lock").thenAccept(exists -> {
     if (!exists) {
       atomix.<DistributedLock>create("lock", DistributedLock::new).thenAccept(lock -> {
         ...
       });
     }
   });
        Parameters:
        key - The key to check.
        Returns:
        A completable future indicating whether the given key exists.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key is null

      • keys

        public CompletableFuture<Set<String>> keys()
        Returns keys of all existing resources.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   Collection<String> resourceKeys = atomix.keys().get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<Collection<String>>keys().thenAccept(resourceKeys -> {
     ...
   });
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the keys of all existing resources.

      • keys

        public <T extends Resource> CompletableFuture<Set<String>> keys(Class<? super T> type)
        Returns the keys of existing resources belonging to a resource type.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   Set<String> resourceKeys = atomix.keys(DistributedLock.class).get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<Set<String>>keys().thenAccept(resourceKeys -> {
     ...
   });
        Type Parameters:
        T - The resource type.
        Parameters:
        type - The resource type by which to filter resources.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the set of resource keys.

      • get

        public <T extends Resource> CompletableFuture<T> get(String key,
                                                     Class<? super T> type)
        Gets or creates the given resource and acquires a singleton reference to it.

        If a resource at the given key already exists, the resource will be validated to verify that its type matches the given type. If no resource yet exists, a new resource will be created in the cluster. Once the session for the resource has been opened, a resource instance will be returned.

        The returned Resource instance will be a singleton reference to an global instance for this node. That is, multiple calls to this method for the same resource will result in the same Resource instance being returned.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   DistributedLock lock = atomix.get("lock", DistributedLock.class).get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<DistributedLock>get("lock", DistributedLock.class).thenAccept(lock -> {
     ...
   });
        Type Parameters:
        T - The resource type.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to get the resource.
        type - The expected resource type.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource has been loaded.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key or type are null

      • get

        public <T extends Resource> CompletableFuture<T> get(String key,
                                                     ResourceType<T> type)
        Gets or creates the given resource and acquires a singleton reference to it.

        If a resource at the given key already exists, the resource will be validated to verify that its type matches the given type. If no resource yet exists, a new resource will be created in the cluster. Once the session for the resource has been opened, a resource instance will be returned.

        The returned Resource instance will be a singleton reference to an global instance for this node. That is, multiple calls to this method for the same resource will result in the same Resource instance being returned.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   DistributedLock lock = atomix.get("lock", DistributedLock.class).get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<DistributedLock>get("lock", DistributedLock.class).thenAccept(lock -> {
     ...
   });
        Type Parameters:
        T - The resource type.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to get the resource.
        type - The expected resource type.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource has been loaded.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key or type are null

      • create

        public <T extends Resource> CompletableFuture<T> create(String key,
                                                        Class<? super T> type)
        Creates a new instance for the given resource.

        If a resource at the given key already exists, the resource will be validated to verify that its type matches the given type. If no resource yet exists, a new resource will be created in the cluster. Once the session for the resource has been opened, a new resource instance will be returned.

        The returned Resource instance will have a unique logical connection to the resource state. This means that operations and events submitted or received by this instance related to this instance only, even if multiple instances of the resource are open on this node. For instance, a lock resource created via this method will behave as a unique reference to the distributed state. Locking a lock acquired via this method will lock only that lock instance and not other instance of the lock on this node.

        To acquire a singleton reference to a resource that is global to this node, use the get(String, ResourceType) method.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   DistributedLock lock = atomix.create("lock", DistributedLock.class).get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<DistributedLock>create("lock", DistributedLock.class).thenAccept(lock -> {
     ...
   });
        Type Parameters:
        T - The resource type.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to create the resource.
        type - The resource type to create.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource has been created.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key or type are null
        ResourceException - if the resource could not be instantiated

      • create

        public <T extends Resource> CompletableFuture<T> create(String key,
                                                        ResourceType<T> type)
        Creates a new instance for the given resource.

        If a resource at the given key already exists, the resource will be validated to verify that its type matches the given type. If no resource yet exists, a new resource will be created in the cluster. Once the session for the resource has been opened, a new resource instance will be returned.

        The returned Resource instance will have a unique logical connection to the resource state. This means that operations and events submitted or received by this instance related to this instance only, even if multiple instances of the resource are open on this node. For instance, a lock resource created via this method will behave as a unique reference to the distributed state. Locking a lock acquired via this method will lock only that lock instance and not other instance of the lock on this node.

        To acquire a singleton reference to a resource that is global to this node, use the get(String, ResourceType) method.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.get() method: 

           
   DistributedLock lock = atomix.create("lock", DistributedLock.class).get();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the result is received in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   atomix.<DistributedLock>create("lock", DistributedLock.class).thenAccept(lock -> {
     ...
   });
        Type Parameters:
        T - The resource type.
        Parameters:
        key - The key at which to create the resource.
        type - The resource type to create.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the resource has been created.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key or type are null
        ResourceException - if the resource could not be instantiated
